data.title: Which are the 10 Countries With the Most Time Zones?
data.meta_description: Discover the 10 countries with the most time zones, including France, Russia, and the USA. Explore how their vast territories influence global timekeeping.
data.meta_site_name: Best Diplomats | Diplomatic Conferences | New York
data.text:
Time zones play a crucial role in how we organize our daily lives across the globe. As the Earth spins, different regions bask in sunlight while others are cloaked in darkness. Some countries are so vast that they span multiple time zones. France, Russia, the United States, Australia, and the United Kingdom are the top five countries with the most time zones. Let’s raise the curtain from the top countries and explore their time zones.

Top 10 Countries with the Most Time Zones

Russia

1- France

France holds the record for the most time zones in the world, possessing 12 distinct time zones due to its numerous overseas territories. When including its claim in Antarctica, the total rises to 13.

1- UTC +01:00 (CET): This is the standard time for Metropolitan France, which includes the mainland and the capital, Paris. It shifts to Central European Summer Time (CEST) during the summer months, which is UTC +02:00.

2- UTC -10:00 (TAHT): Tahiti Time is used in French Polynesia, including the island of Tahiti.

3- UTC -9:30 (MART): Marquesas Time applies to the Marquesas Islands in French Polynesia.

4- UTC -9:00 (GAMT): Gambier Time is observed in the Gambier Islands, also part of French Polynesia.

5- UTC -8:00 (EAST): Easter Island Standard Time is used in Clipperton Island.

6- UTC -4:00 (AST): Atlantic Standard Time is observed in several territories, including Guadeloupe, Martinique, Saint Barthélemy, and Saint Martin.

7- UTC -3:00 (GFT): French Guiana Time is used in French Guiana, located on the northeastern coast of South America.

8- UTC -2:00 (PMDT): Pierre and Miquelon Daylight Time is for Saint Pierre and Miquelon, which observes daylight saving time.

9- UTC +3:00 (EAT): Eastern Africa Time is used in Mayotte, an overseas department in the Indian Ocean.

10- UTC +4:00 (RET): Réunion Time is observed on Réunion Island.

11- UTC +5:00 (TFT): French Southern and Antarctic Time is used in the French Southern Territories.

12- UTC +11:00 (NCT): New Caledonia Time applies to New Caledonia.

13- UTC +12:00 (WFT): Wallis and Futuna Time is used in Wallis and Futuna.

2- Russia

Russia is a country that possesses 11 time zones. The vast territory of Russia stretches from the Baltic Sea in the west to the Pacific Ocean in the east. This geographical expanse results in significant differences in local times across the country.

1- Kaliningrad Time Zone (UTC+2): The westernmost region of Russia, Kaliningrad Oblast, observes Kaliningrad Time. This time zone is shared with some other European countries, such as Poland and Lithuania.

2- Moscow Time Zone (UTC+3): The most populous time zone in Russia is the Moscow Time Zone (MSK), which covers 48 federal subjects in the European part of the country.

3- Samara Time Zone (UTC+4): The Samara Time Zone (SAMT) covers four regions in central Russia: Samara Oblast, Astrakhan Oblast, Ulyanovsk Oblast, and the Udmurt Republic.

4- Yekaterinburg Time Zone (UTC+5): Nine federal districts to the east of the Ural Mountains make up the Yekaterinburg Time Zone (YEKT).

5- Omsk Time Zone (UTC+6): The Omsk Time Zone (OMST) includes one region of southwestern Siberia: Tomsk Oblast.

6- Krasnoyarsk Time Zone (UTC+7): The Krasnoyarsk Time Zone (KRAT) covers six federal districts in central Siberia.

7- Irkutsk Time Zone (UTC+8): The Irkutsk Time Zone (IRKT) includes five regions in eastern Siberia, including the city of Irkutsk.

8- Yakutsk Time Zone (UTC+9): The Yakutsk Time Zone (YAKT) covers the vast Sakha Republic in northeastern Siberia.

9- Vladivostok Time Zone (UTC+10): The Vladivostok Time Zone (VLAT) includes the Primorsky Krai and the Jewish Autonomous Oblast in the Russian Far East.

10- Magadan Time Zone (UTC+11): The Magadan Time Zone (MAGT) covers the Magadan Oblast and the Chukotka Autonomous Okrug in the far northeastern part of Russia.

11- Kamchatka Time Zone (UTC+12): The easternmost time zone in Russia is the Kamchatka Time Zone (PETT), which includes the Kamchatka Peninsula and the Kuril Islands.

3- United States

The United States has nine standard time zones, with additional territories pushing the total to thirteen.

1- Eastern Time Zone (UTC-5/UTC-4): The Eastern Time Zone (ET) covers major cities like New York, Washington D.C., and Atlanta.

2- Central Time Zone (UTC-6/UTC-5): Central Time Zone (CT) includes cities such as Chicago, Dallas, and New Orleans. It covers a large swath of the Midwest and the South.

3- Mountain Time Zone (UTC-7/UTC-6): The Mountain Time Zone (MT) includes states like Colorado and Utah, with cities such as Denver and Salt Lake City.

4- Pacific Time Zone (UTC-8/UTC-7): The Pacific Time Zone (PT) covers the West Coast, including cities like Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Seattle.

5-Alaska Time Zone (UTC-9/UTC-8): Alaska has its own time zone, known as Alaska Time (AKT). Major cities like Anchorage and Juneau fall under this zone.

6- Hawaii-Aleutian Time Zone (UTC-10)

Hawaii operates on Hawaii-Aleutian Time (HAT), which is UTC-10.

7- Atlantic Time Zone (UTC-4): The Atlantic Time Zone (AT) includes Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

8- Samoa Time Zone (UTC-11): American Samoa uses the Samoa Time Zone. It is one of the westernmost territories of the U.S.

9- Chamorro Time Zone (UTC+10): The Chamorro Time Zone covers Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands.

4- Australia

Australia has three main time zones, but when considering its territories, the number rises.

1- Australian Western Standard Time (AWST, UTC+8): The westernmost part of Australia operates on Australian Western Standard Time. This time zone includes the state of Western Australia.

2- Australian Central Standard Time (ACST, UTC+9:30): The Australian Central Standard Time zone covers South Australia, including Adelaide, and the Northern Territory. Interestingly, Broken Hill in New South Wales also observes this time zone.

3- Australian Eastern Standard Time (AEST, UTC+10): The most populous time zone is Australian Eastern Standard Time. It covers New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, and the Australian Capital Territory.

4- Lord Howe Standard Time (LHST, UTC+10:30): Lord Howe Island, situated east of the mainland, has its own time zone.

5- Australian Central Western Standard Time (ACWST, UTC+8:45): In a small area of Western Australia near Eucla, a half-hour time zone exists, known as Australian Central Western Standard Time.

Additional Territories

Australia’s external territories also contribute to its time zone diversity.

Cocos (Keeling) Islands: UTC+6:30

Christmas Island: UTC+7

Norfolk Island: UTC+11

5- United Kingdom

The United Kingdom operates primarily in a single time zone, but its overseas territories expand this to multiple time zones.

1- Greenwich Mean Time (GMT, UTC+0): The standard time zone for the UK is Greenwich Mean Time (GMT). This time zone is used during the winter months. Major cities like London, Edinburgh, and Cardiff follow this time zone.

2- British Summer Time (BST, UTC+1): When summer arrives, the UK shifts to British Summer Time (BST). Cities like London and Manchester operate on BST during this period.

Overseas Territories

Pitcairn Islands: UTC-8

Cayman Islands: UTC-5

British Virgin Islands: UTC-4

Montserrat: UTC-4

Anguilla: UTC-4

Bermuda: UTC-3

Falkland Islands: UTC-3 (FKST during summer)

South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands: UTC-2

Saint Helena: UTC+0

6- Canada

Canada is a vast country that spans six primary time zones.

1- Newfoundland Time Zone (UTC-3:30): The easternmost province, Newfoundland and Labrador, operates on Newfoundland Time. John’s, the provincial capital, is the largest city in this time zone.

2- Atlantic Time Zone (UTC-4): The Atlantic Time Zone covers New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, and parts of Quebec. Cities like Halifax and Fredericton are key locations in this time zone.

3- Eastern Time Zone (UTC-5): The Eastern Time Zone includes Ontario and Quebec, particularly cities like Toronto and Ottawa. This zone is one of the most populated in Canada.

4- Central Time Zone (UTC-6): The parts of Saskatchewan, Ontario, and Manitoba are included in the Central Time Zone.

5- Mountain Time Zone (UTC-7): The Mountain Time Zone includes Alberta and parts of British Columbia, as well as the Northwest Territories. Calgary and Edmonton are prominent cities in this region.

6- Pacific Time Zone (UTC-8): The Pacific Time Zone covers British Columbia and parts of the Yukon. Vancouver is the largest city in this time zone.

7- Denmark

Denmark is a Nordic country known for its history, beautiful landscapes, and culture. While mainland Denmark operates primarily under a single time zone, its territories extend across multiple time zones. Overall, Denmark has five time zones.

1- Central European Time (CET, UTC+1): Mainland Denmark, which includes cities like Copenhagen and Aarhus, follows Central European Time (CET).

2- Central European Summer Time (CEST, UTC+2): During the summer months, Denmark shifts to Central European Summer Time (CEST).

3- Western European Time (WET, UTC+0): The Faroe Islands, an autonomous territory of Denmark located in the North Atlantic, observe Western European Time.

4- Greenland Time Zones

Greenland, the largest island in the world, has three distinct time zones:

Greenwich Mean Time (GMT, UTC+0): The northeast coast of Greenland, including areas like Danmarkshavn, follows Greenwich Mean Time.

East Greenland Time (UTC-1): This time zone is used in places like Ittoqqortoormiit.

West Greenland Time (UTC-3): Cities like Nuuk and Kangerlussuaq operate in this time zone.

5- Atlantic Time (UTC-4): The Pituffik Space Base in Greenland follows Atlantic Time. This time zone aligns with the rules observed in the United States.

8- New Zealand

New Zealand, located in the southwestern Pacific Ocean, primarily operates under two main time zones, but its territories extend this to five.

1- New Zealand Standard Time (NZST, UTC+12): The main time zone for New Zealand is New Zealand Standard Time. This time zone covers the North Island and the South Island, including major cities like Auckland, Wellington, and Christchurch.

2- New Zealand Daylight Time (NZDT, UTC+13): During the summer months, New Zealand shifts to New Zealand Daylight Time (NZDT).

3- Chatham Islands Time (CHAST, UTC+12:45): The Chatham Islands, located about 800 kilometers east of the South Island, have their own unique time zone.

4- Chatham Islands Daylight Time (CHADT, UTC+13:45): During Daylight Saving Time, the Chatham Islands observe Chatham Islands Daylight Time.

5- Tokelau Time (UTC+13): Tokelau, a territory of New Zealand, operates on Tokelau Time.

9- Brazil

Brazil is a vast country that stretches across South America. Due to its size, Brazil spans four primary time zones.

1- Acre Time (ACT, UTC-5): The westernmost time zone is Acre Time. This zone covers the state of Acre and some municipalities in the western Amazon. Cities like Rio Branco fall under this time zone.

2- Amazon Time (AMT, UTC-4): This time zone includes states such as Amazonas, Mato Grosso, and parts of Pará. Major cities like Manaus are located here.

3- Brasília Time (BRT, UTC-3): The most populous time zone is Brasília Time. This zone covers a large part of Brazil, including major cities like São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, and the capital, Brasília. Approximately 90% of the Brazilian population lives in this time zone.

4- Fernando de Noronha Time (FNT, UTC-2): The easternmost time zone is Fernando de Noronha Time. This time zone applies to the archipelago of Fernando de Noronha and a few other small islands off the coast.

10- Mexico

Mexico operates in four distinct time zones.

1- Zona Centro (Central Standard Time): Most of Mexico, including major cities like Mexico City, Guadalajara, and Monterrey, operates on Central Standard Time (CST), also known as Zona Centro. It covers a significant portion of the country, including states such as Aguascalientes, Campeche, Mexico State, Mexico City, and San Luis Potosí.

2- Zona Pacifico (Mountain Standard Time): The western regions of Mexico, including the states of Nayarit, Sinaloa, and Baja California Sur, follow Mountain Standard Time (MST), or Zona Pacifico.

3- Zona Noroeste (Pacific Standard Time): Baja California Norte, which borders California, is in the Pacific Standard Time zone (PST), known as Zona Noroeste.

4- Zona Sureste (Eastern Standard Time): Quintana Roo, famous for tourist destinations like Cancún and Playa del Carmen, operates on Eastern Standard Time (EST), or Zona Sureste.

Conclusion

These ten countries with the most time zones showcase their vast geographical reach and diverse territories. France tops the list. Russia, with its immense landmass, covers multiple time zones from Europe to Asia. The United States and Canada, both large North American countries, also have numerous time zones due to their expansive territories. Australia and Brazil have several time zones due to their continental spans. The United Kingdom and Denmark include various overseas territories, adding to their time zone count. New Zealand and Mexico, though smaller, have multiple time zones due to their geographical diversity.
